text: I'm Shelby Cullinan with today's health news.

At first glance it's hard to see a connection
between sleep hormones and type 2 diabetes.

New research from Sweden's Lund University,
however, found that melatonin impaired insulin

Previous research showed that a gene variant
on melatonin receptor B1 increases the risk

The gene variant increases the effect of the
melatonin receptor on insulin cells.

As a result, the cells become less sensitive
to insulin, which increases the risk of elevated

The research team found that those who carried
the risk gene had significantly lower insulin

All of the study participants had an increase
in blood sugar after three months of melatonin

Those with the carrier gene, however, were
much more likely to have higher blood sugars.
Speak to your doctor for more information.
